items.text: The **Caliphate of Córdoba** ([[LINK|lang_en|Arabic_language|Arabic]]: خِلَاَفَةُ قُرْطُبَةٍ‎; [[LINK|lang_en|DIN_31635|trans.]] *Khilāfat Qurṭuba*) was a state in [[LINK|lang_en|Islamic_Iberia|Islamic Iberia]] along with a part of [[LINK|lang_en|North_Africa|North Africa]] ruled by the [[LINK|lang_en|Umayyad_dynasty|Umayyad dynasty]]. The state, with the capital in [[LINK|lang_en|C%C3%B3rdoba,_Spain|Córdoba]], existed from 929 to 1031. The region was formerly dominated by the Umayyad [[LINK|lang_en|Emirate_of_C%C3%B3rdoba|Emirate of Córdoba]] (756–929). The period was characterized by an expansion of trade and culture, and saw the construction of masterpieces of [[LINK|lang_en|Al-Andalus|al-Andalus]] architecture. In January 929, [[LINK|lang_en|Abd_ar-Rahman_III|Abd ar-Rahman III]] proclaimed himself [[LINK|lang_en|Caliph|Caliph]] (Arabic: خليفة) of Córdoba,[[CITE|3|/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number]] replacing thus his original title of [[LINK|lang_en|Emirate_of_C%C3%B3rdoba|Emir of Córdoba]] (Arabic: أمير قرطبة *'Amīr Qurṭuba*). He was a member of the Umayyad dynasty, which had held the title of [[LINK|lang_en|Emir|Emir]] of Córdoba since 756.

The caliphate disintegrated during the [[LINK|lang_en|Fitna_of_al-Andalus|Fitna of al-Andalus]], a civil war between the descendants of the last caliph, [[LINK|lang_en|Hisham_II|Hisham II]], and the successors of his *[[LINK|lang_en|Hayib|hayib]]* (court official), [[LINK|lang_en|Al-Mansur_Ibn_Abi_Aamir|Al-Mansur]]. In 1031, after years of infighting, the caliphate fractured into a number of independent Muslim *[[LINK|lang_en|Taifa|taifa]]* (kingdoms).[[CITE|4|/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number]]
History
Umayyad Dynasty
Rise

[[LINK|lang_en|Abd_ar-Rahman_I|Abd ar-Rahman I]] became Emir of Córdoba in 756 after six years in exile after the [[LINK|lang_en|Umayyad|Umayyads]] lost the position of Caliph in [[LINK|lang_en|Damascus|Damascus]] to the [[LINK|lang_en|Abbasids|Abbasids]] in 750.[[CITE|5|https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/833763900]] Intent on regaining power, he defeated the area's existing Islamic rulers and united various local [[LINK|lang_en|Fiefdom|fiefdoms]] into an [[LINK|lang_en|Emirate|emirate]].[[CITE|6|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Barton%2C%2037.]] Raids then increased the emirate's size; the first to go as far as [[LINK|lang_en|Corsica|Corsica]] occurred in 806.[[CITE|7|https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/905696269]]

The emirate's rulers used the title "[[LINK|lang_en|Emir|emir]]" or "[[LINK|lang_en|Sultan|sultan]]" until the 10th century. In the early 10th century, [[LINK|lang_en|Abd_ar-Rahman_III|Abd ar-Rahman III]] faced a threatened invasion from North Africa by the [[LINK|lang_en|Fatimid|Fatimids]], a Shiite rival Islamic empire based in [[LINK|lang_en|Cairo|Cairo]]. Since the invading Fatimids claimed the caliphate, Abd ar-Rahman III claimed the title of caliph himself.[[CITE|8|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Barton%2C%2038.]] Prior to Abd ar-Rahman's proclamation as the caliph, the Umayyads generally recognized the Abbasid Caliph of [[LINK|lang_en|Baghdad|Baghdad]] as being the rightful rulers of the Muslim community.[[CITE|9|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=O'Callaghan%2C%20J.%20F.%20%281983%29.%20*A%20History%20of%20Medieval%20]] Even after repulsing the Fatimids, he kept the more prestigious title.[[CITE|10|/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number]] Although his position as caliph was not accepted outside of al-Andalus and its North African affiliates, internally the Spanish Umayyads considered themselves as closer to Muhammad, and thus more legitimate, than the Abbasids.
Prosperity

The caliphate enjoyed increased prosperity during the 10th century. Abd ar-Rahman III united [[LINK|lang_en|Al-Andalus|al-Andalus]] and brought the Christian kingdoms of the north under control by force and through diplomacy. Abd ar-Rahman III stopped the Fatimid advance into Morocco and al-Andalus in order to prevent a future invasion. The plan for a Fatimid invasion was thwarted when Abd ar-Rahman III secured [[LINK|lang_en|Melilla|Melilla]] in 927, [[LINK|lang_en|Ceuta|Ceuta]] in 931, and [[LINK|lang_en|Tangier|Tangier]] in 951.[[CITE|9|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=O'Callaghan%2C%20J.%20F.%20%281983%29.%20*A%20History%20of%20Medieval%20]] This period of prosperity was marked by increasing diplomatic relations with Berber tribes in North Africa, Christian kings from the north, and with France, Germany and Constantinople.[[CITE|11|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Chejne%2C%2035.]] The caliphate became very profitable during the reign of Abd ar-Rahman III, by increasing the public revenue to 6,245,000 dinars from Abd ar-Rahman II. The profits made during this time were divided into three parts: the payment of the salaries and maintenance of the army, the preservation of public buildings, and the needs of the caliph.[[CITE|9|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=O'Callaghan%2C%20J.%20F.%20%281983%29.%20*A%20History%20of%20Medieval%20]] The death of Abd ar-Rahman III led to the rise of his 46-year-old son, [[LINK|lang_en|Al-Hakam_II|Al-Hakam II]], in 961. Al-Hakam II continued his father's policy, dealing humanely with disruptive Christian kings and North African rebels. Al-Hakam's reliance on his advisers was greater than his father's because the previous prosperity under Abd ar-Rahman III allowed al-Hakam II to let the caliphate run by itself. This style of rulership suited al-Hakam II since he was more interested in his scholarly and intellectual pursuits than ruling the caliphate. The caliphate was at its intellectual and scholarly peak under al-Hakam II.[[CITE|12|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Chejne%2C%2037%E2%80%9338.]][[CITE|13|https://books.google.com/books?id=7Z4WBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT44]]

caption.text: The Caliphate of Córdoba under [[LINK|lang_en|Abd_ar-Rahman_III|Abd ar-Rahman III]].

items.text: Fall

The death of al-Hakam II in 976 marked the beginning of the end of the caliphate. Before his death, al-Hakam named his only son [[LINK|lang_en|Hisham_II|Hisham II]] successor. Although the 10-year-old child was ill-equipped to be caliph, [[LINK|lang_en|Al-Mansur_Ibn_Abi_Aamir|Al-Mansur Ibn Abi Aamir]] (top adviser to al-Hakam, also known as [[LINK|lang_en|Almanzor|Almanzor]]), who had sworn an oath of obedience to [[LINK|lang_en|Hisham_II|Hisham II]], pronounced him caliph. Almanzor had great influence over [[LINK|lang_en|Subh_(sultana)|Subh]], the mother and regent of Hisham II. Almanzor, along with Subh, isolated Hisham in Córdoba while systematically eradicating opposition to his own rule, allowing [[LINK|lang_en|Berber_people|Berbers]] from Africa to migrate to al-Andalus to increase his base of support.[[CITE|14|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Chejne%2C%2038%E2%80%9340.]] While Hisham II was caliph, he was merely a figurehead.[[CITE|15|https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=JuVuAwAAQBAJ]] He, his son [[LINK|lang_en|Abd_al-Malik_al-Muzaffar|Abd al-Malik]] (al-Muzaffar, after his 1008 death) and his brother ([[LINK|lang_en|Abd_al-Rahman_Sanchuelo|Abd al-Rahman]]) retained the power nominally held by Caliph Hisham. However, during a raid on the Christian north a revolt tore through Córdoba and Abd al-Rahman never returned.[[CITE|16|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Chejne%2C%2042%E2%80%9343.]][[CITE|17|/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number]]

The title of caliph became symbolic, without power or influence. The death of [[LINK|lang_en|Abd_al-Rahman_Sanchuelo|Abd al-Rahman Sanchuelo]] in 1009 marked the beginning of the [[LINK|lang_en|Fitna_of_al-Andalus|Fitna of al-Andalus]], with rivals claiming to be the new caliph, violence sweeping the caliphate, and intermittent invasions by the [[LINK|lang_en|Hammudid_dynasty|Hammudid dynasty]].[[CITE|13|https://books.google.com/books?id=7Z4WBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT44]]  Beset by factionalism, the caliphate crumbled in 1031 into a number of independent *taifas*, including the [[LINK|lang_en|Taifa_of_C%C3%B3rdoba|Taifa of Córdoba]], [[LINK|lang_en|Taifa_of_Seville|Taifa of Seville]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Taifa_of_Zaragoza|Taifa of Zaragoza]]. The last Córdoban Caliph was [[LINK|lang_en|Hisham_III|Hisham III]] (1027–1031).
Culture

Córdoba was the cultural centre of al-Andalus.[[CITE|18|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Barton%2C%2040%E2%80%9341.]] Mosques, such as the Great Mosque, were the focus of many caliphs' attention. The caliph's palace, [[LINK|lang_en|Medina_Azahara|Medina Azahara]] is on the outskirts of the city, where an estimated 10,000 laborers and artisans worked for decades on the palace, constructing the decorated buildings and courtyards filled with fountains and airy domes.[[CITE|19|https://archive.org/details/peacebeuponyoust00kara]] Córdoba was also the intellectual centre of al-Andalus, with translations of ancient Greek texts into Arabic, Latin and Hebrew. During the reign of [[LINK|lang_en|Al-Hakam_II|al-Hakam II]], the royal library possessed an estimated 500,000 volumes.[[CITE|13|https://books.google.com/books?id=7Z4WBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT44]][[CITE|20|https://www.britannica.com/topic/information-processing#ref287320]] For comparison, the [[LINK|lang_en|Abbey_of_Saint_Gall|Abbey of Saint Gall]] in Switzerland contained just over 100 volumes.[[CITE|13|https://books.google.com/books?id=7Z4WBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT44]] The university in Córdoba became the most celebrated in the world. It was attended by Christian students from all Western Europe, as well as Muslim students. The university produced one hundred and fifty authors. Other universities and libraries were scattered through Spain during this golden age.[[CITE|21|/wiki/Francis_Preston_Venable]] During the Caliphate period, relations between Jews and Arabs were cordial; Jewish stonemasons helped build the columns of the Great Mosque.

Advances in science, history, geography, philosophy, and language occurred during the Caliphate.[[CITE|22|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Barton%2C%2042.]] Al-Andalus was subject to eastern cultural influences as well. The musician [[LINK|lang_en|Ziryab|Ziryab]] is credited with bringing hair and clothing styles, [[LINK|lang_en|Toothpaste|toothpaste]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Deodorant|deodorant]] from [[LINK|lang_en|Baghdad|Baghdad]] to the Iberian peninsula.[[CITE|23|https://archive.org/details/goldenageofmoor00vans]]

caption.text: Interior of the [[LINK|lang_en|Mezquita|Mezquita]] (Mosque), one of the finest examples of [[LINK|lang_en|Umayyad_architecture|Umayyad architecture]] in Spain.

items.text: Economy

The economy of the caliphate was diverse and successful, with trade predominating. Muslim trade routes connected al-Andalus with the outside world via the Mediterranean. Industries revitalized during the caliphate included [[LINK|lang_en|Textile|textiles]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ceramic|ceramics]], [[LINK|lang_en|Glassware|glassware]], metalwork, and agriculture. The Arabs introduced crops such as rice, watermelon, banana, eggplant and hard wheat. Fields were irrigated with [[LINK|lang_en|Water_wheels|water wheels]]. Some of the most prominent merchants of the caliphate were Jews. Jewish merchants had extensive networks of trade that stretched the length of the Mediterranean Sea. Since there was no international banking system at the time, payments relied on a high level of trust, and this level of trust could only be cemented through personal or family bonds, such as marriage. Jews from al-Andalus, Cairo, and the Levant all intermarried across borders. Therefore, Jewish merchants in the caliphate had counterparts abroad that were willing to do business with them.[[CITE|24|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Karabell%2C%20Zachary%20%282007%29.%20*Peace%20Be%20Upon%20You%3A%20The%20]]
Religion

The caliphate had an ethnically, culturally, and religiously diverse society. A minority of ethnic Muslims of Arab descent occupied the priestly and ruling positions, another Muslim minority were primarily soldiers and native Hispano-Gothic converts (who comprised most of the Muslim minority) were found throughout society. Jews comprised about ten percent of the population: little more numerous than the Arabs and about equal in numbers to the Berbers. They were primarily involved in business and intellectual occupations. The indigenous Christian [[LINK|lang_en|Mozarabs|Mozarab]] majority were Catholic Christians of the Visigothic rite, who spoke a variant of Latin close to [[LINK|lang_en|Spanish_language|Spanish]], [[LINK|lang_en|Portuguese_language|Portuguese]] or [[LINK|lang_en|Catalan_language|Catalan]] with an Arabic influence. The Mozarabs were the lower strata of society, heavily taxed with few civil rights and culturally influenced by the Muslims. Ethnic Arabs occupied the top of the social hierarchy; Muslims had a higher social standing than Jews, who had a higher social standing than Christians. Christians and Jews were considered *[[LINK|lang_en|Dhimmi|dhimmis]]*, required to pay [[LINK|lang_en|Jizya|jizya]] (a tax for the wars against Christian kingdoms in the north).[[CITE|25|http://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/cjnconnect/blogs/article_057a78b4-3f44-5375-a20d-a850a62b2194.html]]

The word of a Muslim was valued more than that of a Christian or Jew in court. Some offenses were harshly punished when a Jew or Christian was the perpetrator against a Muslim even if the offenses were permitted when the perpetrator was a Muslim and the victim a non-Muslim. Half of the population in Córdoba is reported to have been Muslim by the 10th century, with an increase to 70 percent by the 11th century. That was due less to local conversion than to Muslim immigration from the rest of the [[LINK|lang_en|Iberian_Peninsula|Iberian Peninsula]] and [[LINK|lang_en|North_Africa|North Africa]]. Combined with the mass expulsions of Christians from Córdoba after a revolt in the city, that explains why, during the caliphate, Cordoba was the greatest Muslim centre in the region. Jewish immigration to Córdoba also increased then. Christians saw their status decline from their rule under the Visigoths, meanwhile the status of Jews improved during the Caliphate.  While Jews were persecuted under the Visigoths, Jewish communities benefited from Umayyad rule by obtaining more freedom, affluence and a higher social standing.[[CITE|24|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Karabell%2C%20Zachary%20%282007%29.%20*Peace%20Be%20Upon%20You%3A%20The%20]]
Population

According to Thomas Glick, "Despite the withdrawal of substantial numbers during the drought and famine of the 750's, fresh Berber migration from North Africa was a constant feature of Andalusi history, increasing in tempo in the tenth century. Hispano-Romans who converted to Islam, numbering six or seven millions, comprised the majority of the population and also occupied the lowest rungs on the social ladder."[[CITE|26|null]][[CITE|27|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=%22The%20rate%20of%20conversion%20is%20slow%20until%20the%20tenth%20ce]]  It is also estimated that the capital city held around 450,000 people, making it the largest city in Europe at the time.[[CITE|28|/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number]]
List of rulers

According to historians, the emirs and caliphs comprising the Umayyad dynasty in Al-Andalus were the sons of concubine slaves (almost all Iberians from the north of the peninsula). The founder of the dynasty, Abd ar-Rahman I, was the son of a Berber woman; his son (and successor as emir) had a Spanish mother.[[CITE|29|/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number]] As such, the genome of Hisham II, tenth ruler of the Umayyad dynasty, "would have mostly originated from the Iberian Peninsula and would not be more than 0.1% of Arab descent, although the Y chromosome would still be of fully Arab origin".[[CITE|30|/wiki/PubMed_Identifier]][[CITE|31|http://hrcak.srce.hr/file/94109]]

[Emir Abdullah died on] 16 Oct., 912 after 26 years of inglorious rule leaving his fragmented and bankrupt kingdom to his grandson ‘Abd ar-Rahman. The following day, the new sultan received the oath of allegiance at a ceremony held in the "Perfect salon" (al-majils al-kamil) of the Alcazar.

"This day, Mary 15, in Jewish history". Cleveland Jewish News.

"The rate of conversion is slow until the tenth century (less than one-quarter of the eventual total number of converts had been converted); the explosive period coincides closely with the reign of 'Abd al-Rahman III (912–961); the process is completed (eighty percent converted) by around 1100. The curve, moreover, makes possible a reasonable estimate of the religious distribution of the population. Assuming that there were seven million Hispano-Romans in the peninsula in 711 and that the numbers of this segment of the population remained level through the eleventh century (with population growth balancing out Christian migration to the north), then by 912 there would have been approximately 2.8 million indigenous Muslims (muwalladûn) plus Arabs and Berbers. At this point Christians still vastly outnumbered Muslims. By 1100, however, the number of indigenous Muslims would have risen to a majority of 5.6 million.", (Glick 2005, pp. 23-24)

Tertius Chandler, *Four Thousand Years of Urban Growth: An Historical Census*, Lewiston, NY: The Edwin Mellen Press, 1987. ISBN 0-88946-207-0.  Figures in main tables are preferentially cited. Part of Chandler's estimates are summarized or modified at The Institute for Research on World-Systems; *Largest Cities Through History* by Matt T. Rosenberg; or The Etext Archives Archived 2008-02-11 at the Wayback Machine.  Chandler defined a city as a continuously built-up area (urban) with suburbs but without farmland inside the municipality.
